 1 REPUBLIC OF YEMEN TRANSPORT REHABILITATION PROJECT STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT I. INTRODUCTION 1.1 The proposed Transport Rehabilitation Project in the Republic of Yemen (ROY), is designed to address needs in the country's transport sector arising both out of the damages suffered in the recent civil war (May-June, 1994), and from neglect of road maintenance which now necessitates reconstruction of sections of the road network. War related emergency reconstruction works to be financed under the project are, reconstruction of the terminal building and replacement of the control tower at the Aden International Airport, which were badly damaged in the fighting; the terminal building took a direct hit and has not been in use since the war. Road rehabilitation works to be financed under the project include two road sections: a 100- km section of the Shukra-Am Ayn-Naqaba road between Aden and Mukalla which is the main link to the eastern parts of the country; and the Hodeidah-Salif Road which links the new deepwater port of Salif on the Red Sea coast to the main road network and to the city of Hodeidah. 1.2 Since the road rehabilitation works to be financed under the Credit have been necessitated by inadequate maintenance performance in the road sector, the project includes components to assist the Government in strengthening the road maintenance function in the country. To this end, the project will assist in the establishment of a Road Maintenance Fund with revenues generated from road user charges, and in putting in place a maintenance planning, budgeting and contracting capability which, in conjunction with an assured source of funding, would remove the primary obstacles to effective maintenance of the road network. A. Country Background 1.3 The Republic of Yemen occupies an area of about 530,000 sq. km. of largely mountainous and desertic terrain in the southwestern part of the Arabian Peninsula. Of a total population of about 16 million (1995), about 12 million are concentrated in the northern governorates which cover less than a third of the land area. There are five distinct geographic regions: the coastal plain along the Red Sea (the Tihama Plain); the Indian Ocean desertic littoral, with its strategic centers of population such as Aden; the rugged central and southern highlands, rising to about 2500 m., where the bulk of the population lives; the eastern plateau; and the Rub Al Khali desert. Only about 3 percent of the land is arable, mainly in the central and southern highlands where rainfall is highest, in the Tihama plain, and in the wadis (river valleys) of the eastern plateau. 1.4 Though the overall output of the Yemeni economy has improved recently, the country still faces a difficult situation. Following a slump in economic activity after the Gulf War, GDP rebounded in 1992. Growth accelerated in 1993 and 1994, averaging 5.8 percent, primarily due to rapidly expanding oil production, which increased by 19 and 56 percent in 1993 and 1994. This growth however did not benefit all segments of the population; unemployment which had averaged 25-30 percent during 1990-93 is estimated to have risen further in 1994. With a population of about 14 million, per capita GNP is estimated at US$280, or well below the IDA eligibility cut-off. The country's economic difficulties stem from both internal and external factors. Internally, unification caused substantial increases in Government expenditures which could not be covered by non-inflationary means, and also weakened the Government's ability to implement policies
 2 to deal with a deteriorating macro-economic situation. Externally, the Gulf crisis led to a drop in financial inflows - both aid and private remittances, and to a large increase in the labor force, due to the return of Yemeni workers from Gulf countries. The civil war in 1994 only worsened an already difficult situation. 1.5 The Government's preoccupation with the unification process and the hiatus caused by the hostilities in 1994, overshadowed efforts to halt the deterioration in public finances. The budget deficit remained very large, at over 18 percent of GDP in 1992 and 1993, and increased to an estimated 21.5 percent in 1994. The deficit has customarily been financed through external borrowing and through domestic bank financing. External financing has declined and now amounts to only 1.5 percent of GDP, and in the absence of a well developed market for treasury instruments, deficit financing was largely in the form of money creation. As a result, the parallel market exchange rate for the Yemeni Rial (YR) rapidly depreciated; by March 1995, while the official rate was YR12/$, it was trading at YR142/$ on the parallel market. Following devaluation of the official rate to YR50/$ in April 1995, the parallel market rate depreciated a bit further to YR150/$. 1.6 IDA's Country Assistance Strategy for Yemen, being presented to the Board along with this project, has the following main objectives: (i) support stabilization, structural reforms and social protection measures; (ii) improve portfolio implementation and the sustainability of past and future investments; and (iii) promote sustainable natural and human resources development. This project supports and is fully consistent with the proposed IDA assistance strategy: it would restore key economic infrastructure while improving the sustainability of transport sector investments by funding maintenance through a system of user charges. It would also promote macro-economic stabilization by reducing the burden on the Government's budget of financing road maintenance, the costs of which will now be recovered from road users. B. IDA Sector Role and Strategy 1.7 Since 1970, IDA has contributed to the development of ROY's transport system and institutions through one port and seven highway projects in the former YAR; and an engineering credit, one port and six highway projects in the former PDRY. In addition, the Multi-Mode Transport Project (Credit 2177- YEM) which was approved in 1990 after the creation of the unified ROY supported construction of roads, and technical assistance and equipment for the aviation and ports sectors. The first seven highway projects in the north (Credits 315-YAR, 558-YAR, 794-YAR, 1267-YAR, 1413-YAR, 1726-YAR and 1848-YAR), and the engineering credit and the first seven highway projects in the south (Credits 512-YDR, 240-YDR, 560-YDR, 1144-YDR, 1295-YDR, 1617-YDR and 1823-YDR) have been completed. 1.8 Previous IDA highway projects in the north and south, assisted in the establishment and consolidation of highway agencies. Two public sector construction units were also established to implement road works due to a lack of domestic capacity in the road construction sector. A Vocational Training Ceniter was also established under the Third Highway Project in Taiz, as a training facility for all road maintenance staff. In addition, IDA credits assisted in the preparation of a Highway Master Plan (February 1986), and a Transport Sector Study (June 1984) which have helped define investment and institutional needs. 1.9 The two completed port projects, have also achieved important physical targets, and the PCR/PPAR No. 5465 for the port project in the north (Credit 714-YAR) found that the project was instrumental in expanding port capacity significantly. Similarly, the PCR/PPAR No. 5982 for the Aden Port Rehabilitation Project in the south (Credit 584-YDR) acknowledges that the project helped to cope with an unforeseen increase in port traffic in the late 1970's and early 1980's; however, changes in shipping patterns following the closure of the Suez Canal, and later, competition from other Red Sea ports caused Aden to lose much of its business in bunkering and ship services. Manpower training in the ports and civil aviation sectors are being addressed under the ongoing Multi-Mode Transport Project (Credit 2177-YEM).
 3 1.10 Since Yemen's primary road network is approaching completion, IDA's transport sector strategy focusses on: maintenance of existing assets (as in the present project); selective expansion of the road network providing access to areas with high economic potential; and the upgrading of operational and financial management. A study now being initiated under a Project Preparation Facility seeks to prioritize maintenance and rehabilitation needs of the existing road network, and the present project addresses some of the more pressing institutional and financial needs affecting maintenance of the road network.(') 1.11 The experience with project implementation in Yemen has been mixed, but since the civil war the remaining project in the sector (Multi-mode Transport project) has been performing well. The monthly progress of physical works is acceptable, the project is disbursing well, no extension of the closing date seems necessary at this stage, and there are no problems with the Special Account and Audit Reporting. This is mainly due to simplicity in project design and straightforward procurement arrangements. The present project has therefore been designed accordingly with most of the procurement to be accomplished through four large civil works contracts. Credit covenants have also been designed so that implementation of otherwise independent project components is not disrupted by defaults on covenants relating to other components. II. SECTORAL BACKGROUND 2.1 Yemen's transport sector, like most other parts of the economy, is presently comprised of a mix of the systems which existed in the former PDRY and YAR prior to unification. In the south, the sector was dominated by centralized planning and public enterprises, while in the north, more traditional forms of organization have been the norm, with numerous anachronistic practices and distortions. Since unification the country as a whole has been moving toward more liberalized, market economy based forms of organization, and this is true in the transport sector also. A. The Road Sector 2.2 Over the decade 1980-90, the paved road network in Yemen grew rapidly from about 2,900 kms. to 4,900 kms, and in early 1993, the length of the paved network, including projects under construction stood at 5,734 luns. Average daily traffic volumes range from around 10,000 ADT (near Sana'a) to just under 1,000 ADT on most of the network, with traffic volumes in the north generally exceeding 2,000 ADT, while in the south most roads carry less than 2,000 ADT with a few exceptions near Aden and in the Hadramout valley. Since unification of the country in 1990, traffic growth rates have been around 8 percent per annum, reflecting increases in the vehicle fleet resulting from the large numbers of vehicles brought into the country by the returnees after the Gulf crisis, and also increases in trade and transport among various parts of the newly unified country. Rapid expansion of the road network, which essentially, doubled in the last 15 years, has caused maintenance of existing roads to be neglected, and deteriorating roads now cause large economic losses through increased vehicle operating costs, as well as for reconstruction of roads which have deteriorated to the point of structural failure. Rehabilitation and maintenance of the road network has, therefore, become an urgent priority in the sector. 2.3 Key issues in the sector include inadequate funding of road maintenance, low cost recovery, overloading of trucks and high axle loads, and institutional weaknesses in planning. B. Civil Aviation 2.4 As in the case of the roads sector, the civil aviation sector comprises a mix of systems that existed, prior to unification of the country, in the Civil Aviation Department (CAD) of the former PDRY, and in the Civil Aviation and Meteorological Authority (CAMA) of the former YAR. The scope of operations, assets and organization of the present CAMA, which absorbed CAD at unification, have undergone radical changes first as a result of unification (1990), more recently due to the Gulf crisis (1991), and finally due to the civil war (May-June, 1994) in which considerable damage was suffered at the Aden International Airport. 2.5 Following unification in 1990, CAMA became responsible for the combined airspace of the unified country, and given the vast geographical extent of the former PDRY, this was a considerable expansion in the airspace controlled by CAMA. It also absorbed a large number of staff of the former CAD whose policy had been to carry out most works using its own staff, whereas CAMA relied to a far greater extent on contracting. CAMA also acquired from CAD a completely different mix of equipment, mnuch of it supplied from eastern bloc sources, which caused difficulties in obtaining spares, inter-operability and maintenance. The Gulf crisis in 1991 precipitated another major change; up until then Saudi Arabia had been supporting all air traffic services in the northern Governorates, and controlling the upper airspace from Jeddah. When relations with Saudi Arabia deteriorated during the Gulf crisis, the Saudis withdrew support, and the entire
 S responsibility, and financial burden, of managing the airspace fell on CAMA. The most recent crisis, further strained CAMA due to the large losses of equipment and facilities suffered at AIA which had become the primary base for air traffic services following the withdrawal of Saudi assistance. These events have resulted in a considerably weakened sector significantly compromising civil aviation safety in the country. The Civil Aviation National Plan-2005 (CANP-2005), prepared by international consultants under European Union assistance in 1992 (prior to the most recent crisis), had identified numerous critical deficiencies in the sector, and the losses suffered in the civil war have now exacerbated what was already a difficult situation. CANP- 2005 undertook an extensive assessment of past air traffic trends and prospects for the future, for the 5 international and 14 domestic airports in the country. Its ten-member Board of Directors includes senior managers of CAMA, one representative each from the Ministry of Transport and the Air Force, and the Chairman of the national airline. The Chairman of CAMA also has executive responsibility for running CAMA. The Board functions largely as a management committee rather than a body which exercises oversight over management. Key issues facing CAMA are discussed briefly below, and a more detailed discussion is in the Annex. 2.7 The most critical issues facing CAMA at present are a lack of trained manpower and their extremely weak financial situation. The organization expects to lose many senior staff in the next five years when the staff occupying senior positions retire. Low civil service salaries makes it difficult to recruit and retain qualified personnel. An experienced CAMA technician earns a third to one half the salary of a similarly qualified technician working for the national airline, which has a special arrangement allowing much higher salary scales. CAMA also loses trained technicians to the oil companies working in Yemen, who have a need for trained electronics technicians. CAMA's two training institutes at Sana'a and Aden, once considered a

CAMA's financial condition is precarious, and presently its revenues barely suffice to pay for salaries and the agency is dependent on Government subsidies to cover a bare minimum of operating expenses. It is dependent on donor/Government funding for all its development expenditures, and even items such as spare parts and paint for marking runways often need to be funded by donors. The reasons for CAMA's weak financial condition include: (a) Low tariffs - a revision of CAMA's tariffs is now under consideration, however, even with the tariff increase CAMA revenues will recover only two thirds of its expenditures (see Annex 4); (b) Overstaffing primarily due to the absorption of large numbers of CAD staff; (c) Non-payment or delayed payment by the national carriers who now owe CAMA the equivalent of a year's worth of CAMA revenues; and (d) Loss of significant overflight revenues due to inadequacies in billing and financial systems. CAMA's income statements for FY93, FY94, and estimates/projections for the years 1995, 2000, 2005 are in Annex 4. Projections are made for two scenarios - retaining present tariffs and with the increased tariff now under consideration - and show that even with the increased tariff, CAMA continues to make losses. 2.8 In view of the present incomplete understanding of the constraints and options the civil aviation sector faces from an institutional development standpoint, it is advisable that, as a first step, an institutional development strategy and policy study be undertaken and TORs for such a study have been agreed with IDA. The study would review the current situation, identify options and recommend a course of action with regard to a number of policy areas such as the role of the private sector, organizational structure, tariff setting and financing, responsibility for negotiating bilateral air transport agreements, staffing and training, remuneration, etc., all of which crucially impact on the ability to deliver safe and cost-effective air transport services, without burdening the government with having to finance large deficits in CAMA's budget. The principles which would guide the development of Civil Aviation policy have been discussed and are set out in a Letter of Civil Aviation Policy from the Government to IDA (Annex 5). III. Evaluation Methodology for the Road Component 4.3 The Highway Design and Maintenance Standards Model (HDM-III) developed by the World Bank was utilized to evaluate the road components of the project. HDM simulates the behavior of a road pavement under given traffic loads, maintenance strategies and rehabilitation options. It also assesses the costs of operating various classes of vehicles over the road as the condition of the pavement changes. By evaluating the road's condition and vehicle operating costs with and without the proposed rehabilitation measures, it is able to assess the benefits of the rehabilitation. Key elements of such an exercise are assessments of traffic volumes, existing and projected, for various classes of vehicles, modelling vehicle operating costs and modelling road deterioration. 4.4 Traffic Projections. Table 1 of Annex 10 presents traffic projections for the two road sections for a period of 20 years. Traffic growth rates estimated for the 100 km Am Ayn-Naqabah section is 6 percent annually, and the section now carries 1200 vehicles per day on average. The projected growth rate is based on observed growth rates for traffic on other sections of the Aden - Mukalla road. On the Hodeidah-Salif road, traffic is expected to grow at a high rate owing to the construction of the new deepwater port at Salif, and the growth rate on this section is projected at 8 percent per annum for the first 10 years, and at 5 percent subsequently; presently the road carries about 660 vehicles per day on average. 4.5 Vehicle Operating Costs. For the with project and without project cases, vehicle operating costs (per vehicle-kl) were computed, using the HDM-III model, for five classes of vehicles as a function of the road geometry, vehicle characteristics and the yearly roughness estimated using HDM-III (see Annex 10, Table 3). These unit vehicle operating costs were used to compute the benefits derived from rehabilitation of the road. 4.6 Road Deterioration. For each road segment, the yearly road deterioration (roughness) with the project and without the project was estimated using HDM-III as a function of the estimated traffic, loading, environment and construction characteristics (see Annex 10, Tables 4A, 4B, 4C and 4D). The HDM-III model was also used to define the optimal maintenance strategy (operation and timing) after the completion of construction, e.g., an overlay in yeir 2009. 4.7 Both construction costs and vehicle operating costs were converted to economic costs by eliminating taxes, duties and subsidies. The distortion due to the difference between the official and parallel market exchange rates was eliminated by expressing the unit vehicle operating costs in dollar terms, and by also computing the project costs (construction and future maintenance) in dollars terms (see Annex 10, Table 2).

Road User Charges 8. Previous IDA Credits, 1848-YAR and 1823-YDR, required that road user charges be reviewed, and the former agreement also called for a review of petroleum pricing. While road user charges have been revised from time to time, cost recovery in the road sector has not kept pace with road expenditures largely due to the difficulty of raising significant amounts of resources through instruments such as vehicle license and registration fees. The problems associated with these instruments has prompted the Government to consider mobilizing resources for the sector through a surcharge on fuel sales, which is an instrument that has been used successfully in a number of countries. A road user surcharge (RUS) imposed on fuel sales has a number of advantages: (a) it is directly related to the extent of road use; (b) the burden is spread over a period of time and each payment is relatively small thereby avoiding the difficulties associated with collection of large payments such as an annual road tax; and (c) it does not have any perverse effects such as the safety problems associated with instruments such as a surcharge on tyres.

This stage is followed by a phase of increasing deterioration; first slowly, but then rapidly accelerating into 'fair condition', which ends within a few years in radical structural failure ('poor condition'). For the unwary, this characteristic of paved roads tends to disguise future maintenance requirements of young road networks. During the first phase, maintenance needs are minimal, and a paved road can be kept in good condition by fairly inexpensive routine maintenance. In the subsequent phase of increasing deterioration (into fair condition), the pavement can be restored to good condition. This can be done by patching and resealing, or by strengthening the pavement with an overlay. The latter, which is a moderately costly measure, restores the road's structural strength and riding quality so as to meet traffic requirements for the next several years, thus starting a new pavement cycle. With appropriate routine maintenance and timely resealing or strengthening, a paved road should be kept from deteriorating into poor condition, which requires far more costly reconstruction. Broadly speaking, the total costs of road transport are made up of vehicle operating costs and the investment and maintenance costs related to provision of road services. Except where traffic is very light, the vehicle operating costs constitute the major part of total road transport costs. This has important implications for road management and maintenance. As vehicle operating costs are closely related to road condition as measured by the 'roughness', the development of road user costs on a paved road will follow the same non-linear path as in Figure 1. Hence, the costs to the road users increase progressively when the road is allowed to develop into the critical life-cycle stage. As Vehicle Operating Costs (VOC) constitute such a large part of total road transport costs, even a small percentage increase in the VOC from rougher roads is significant, outweighing the cost savings from deferred maintenance. Continued under-financing of mainte- nance may thus lead to many times its costs in higher vehicle operating costs as well as higher rehabilitation costs. Ill. As the project involves two separate implementing agencies it has been sub-divided in two parts, one for each agency, each to be implemented independently of the other. 2. Part A: Ministry of Construction, Housing and Urban Planning would implement this part, which includes the following components: Road Rehabilitation (a) Hodeidah - Salif Road (US$10.3 million)('): A 65 km section of this road which connects the Port of Salif to the main road network at Hodeidah, is presently in very poor condition. It was originally constructed as a gravel road with a thin bituminous surface treatment. Heavy vehicle traffic associated with development of the Port of Salif for bulk cargoes, has caused the road to deteriorate, and now the road requires reconstruction in parts and an AC overlay of the remainder, to accommodate the increases in traffic expected with the completion of the major grain handling port now under construction at Salif. The road also carries bulk traffic generated by the Yemen Salt & Gypsum Co. which produces or imports about 500,000 tons of gypsum, cement and salt at its facilities in Salif. Presently, traffic on the road is about 660 vehicles per day on average. (b) Am Ayn - Naqabah Road (US$10.0 million): This component finances rehabilitation of the northeastern 100 km of this road, with the southern section being rehabilitated by GCRB with financing from the Government. The road section is in poor condition and will require reconstruction over a considerable portion of its length and resurfacing/overlays on the remainder. The road is the main link between Aden and Mukalla and carries all of the traffic between the eastern region and the rest of the country. Presently, traffic volumes average about 1,200 vehicles per day. Road Maintenance Fund/Yemen Road Fund Board (c) Institutional Development Technical Assistance to the Yemen Road Fund Board (US$0.74 million): Technical assistance would be provided to assist the Government in establishing the new Road Maintenance Fund and the associated technical office to manage the highway system including road maintenance and the Road Maintenance Fund. This component would also assist in commercializing GCRB's and PCRC's construction and maintenance operations by improving its cost accounting system to enable full costing in the execution and planning of works. This would assist the Government in determining how efficient and competitive GCRB and PCRC are in relation to the private sector road construction and maintenance contractors. Draft TOR for this component has been reviewed by IDA. a These are total base costs including the Government's contribution.
 Annex 6 Page 2 of 5 52 (d) Equipment, Software and Installation of a Maintenance Planning, Programming and Budgeting System (US$2.0 million): The capacity both at the central and govemorate level for determining maintenance needs based on regular condition surveys of the main road network is extremely weak. Strengthening this capacity will require equipment such as Bump Integrator, Falling Weight Deflectometers, Dynamic Cone Penetrometers, etc. It would also require computers, software and the setting up of the system including associated training to make it operational. Establishment of such a system will require actions both at the Office of the National Highways Board and at the local level in the Maintenance Departments in each Govemorate. The project will finance a contract under which an international firm will provide a comprehensive package of support, mainly in the form of supply of necessary equipment and associated systems needed to implement the system. TORs for this consultancy contract has been reviewed by IDA. (e) Study for Planning & Prioritizing Maintenance Needs (US$1.5 million): In view of the poor performance in the area of road maintenance, the Government recently embarked on an effort to improve planning and implementation of maintenance works for the main road network. A study of maintenance needs for 2000 km (out of 5000 km of main roads) of "poor" and "fair" condition roads is to be financed under the project. The study will inventory the existing condition of the network, prioritized maintenance needs and develop detailed designs for rehabilitation of the worst 800 kms. Rehabilitation works would be financed by the Road Maintenance Fund (see above). (f) Implementation Supervision Consultants (US$1.5 million): Technical assistancewould also be provided for construction supervision and supervision of the above project components. A Project Implementation Unit, supported by the supervision consultants, would be established under the Ministry of Construction, Housing and Urban Planning to oversee the components in Part A of the project. 3. Part B: Civil Aviation and Meteorological Authority would implement Part B, which mainly comprises emergency reconstruction and technical assistance: Emergency Rehabilitation of the Aden International Airport (a) Aden International Airport Terminal Reconstruction (US$7.0 million): The AIA Terminal, which was constructed in 1986, was bombed during the civil war (May-June 1994). The damages include about 15 percent of the civil works structures, all of the services such as the air conditioning system, electrical system, passenger information system, baggage handling system, etc. An assessment of the damages made by the international consultants who originally designed the terminal has estimated the reconstruction costs. Detailed engineering of reconstruction works is needed and is provided for under the technical assistance component (see below). (b) New Control Tower and Technical Building at AIA (US$6.0 million): The existing tower and technical buildings are old and have been slated for replacement for some time. These buildings, and the communications/navaids equipment and their repair facilities housed there, also suffered considerable damage during the civil war. Detailed design and bidding documents for the new tower and technical building have been prepared under French bilateral assistance, and France has expressed its willingness to finance the equipment and related training, provided Government arranges for construction of the tower and technical building. This project would finance the civil works, including all building services, so as to provide completed buildings adequate to receive the equipment (worth about US$5.0 million) to be provided under French bilateral assistance.

doc.repnme: Republic of Yemen - Transport Rehabilitation Project
doc.abstracts: The primary objective of the Transport Rehabilitation Project is to rehabilitate critical components of the country's road and civil aviation infrastructure; secondarily, the project seeks to improve institutional capacity in these sectors for planning and maintenance of existing assets. As the project involves two separate implementing agencies - the Ministry of Construction, Housing and Urban Planning (MOC) and the Civil Aviation and Meteorological Authority (CAMA) - it is divided into two parts, one for each agency, each to be implemented independently of the other. MOC will implement the following: 1) Hodeidah-Salif, 65 km road rehabilitation; 2) Am Ayn-Naqabah, 100 km road rehabilitation; 3) equipment, software and training for maintenance planning; 4) assistance to the newly created Yemen Road Fund Board; 5) study for planning and prioritizing road maintenance needs and detailed design for rehabilitation of key highway links; and 6) implementation and construction supervision consultants. CAMA will implement: 1) Aden International Airport (AIA) terminal reconstruction; 2) new control tower and technical building at AIA; 3) communications/navaids equipment; 4) safety equipment; 5) civil aviation strategy and policy study; and 6) implementation, design and construction supervision.
